metadata.h1: Compensating for NLP’s Lack of Understanding
metadata.description: The saying “a picture is worth a thousand words” does something of an injustice to the medium of language. It suggests that words are an inefficient form of communication when in fact the opposite is…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Reducing gender bias in Google Translate

all_paragraphs: The saying “a picture is worth a thousand words” does something of an injustice to the medium of language. It suggests that words are an inefficient form of communication when in fact the opposite is true. When humans use language to communicate, so much is left out because the speaker and listener share experience of the same world, which makes explicit statements about that shared world unnecessary in everyday speech. For example, if I say to you “the vase is on its side, rolling along the table,” I don’t need to also tell you that the vase is made of fragile stuff (it’s a reasonable assumption that it is), or that the table doesn’t have edges that will stop the vase’s rolling, or that as a result the vase will likely roll off the table, or that gravity will make the vase to fall to the floor, which is hard and will therefore cause the fragile vase to shatter. It’s enough for me to say “the vase is on its side, rolling along the table” for you to know the vase will likely smash to pieces unless someone intervenes.

What we leave out of our talk is all the knowledge that we can reasonably assume that our listeners also possess. Quite literally, an entire world is left out, and that’s what makes Natural Language Processing (NLP), the field concerned with getting machines to make sense of language, so difficult. While a picture may be worth a thousand words, they are mostly words that nobody would ever bother to utter. Imagine a picture of a dog running for a ball in a park. If you were looking at such a picture and were asked to describe what you saw, would you mention that the grass is green? That’s the kind of information that comes for free in image recognition tasks, but is totally absent from the data used for NLP tasks.

To my mind, these facts make NLP by far the most interesting area in Artificial Intelligence. Currently, machines have no knowledge at all of the world, and as a result no ability to truly understand language. So all the incredible advances in NLP recently, such as the great leaps in Machine Translation capability, have happened in spite of this lack of understanding. This raises two interesting questions:

We can’t know the answer to the first question, although it’s an interesting one to explore. Does imbuing computers with knowledge of the world, i.e., commonsense knowledge, amount to creating so-called Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)? Or are there ways of supplying such knowledge that stop short of AGI but are sufficient to the task of Natural Language Understanding (NLU)? Perhaps knowledge graphs are the key? Or maybe it’s something else entirely. DARPA recently launched the Machine Common Sense program to tackle exactly this problem. It’s also a primary focus of the Allen Institute for AI. While I agree that such research is immensely important for getting a handle on the scope of the problem and how to measure progress towards solving it, I must confess to being skeptical about practical or useful outcomes here. And as someone who works in industry and is looking to solve current business problems using NLP, I can’t help finding the second question much more compelling. We need to be able to recognise the limits of NLP in the absence of true understanding, because that’s the actual state of play on the ground today.

Looking at current NLP applications, Machine Translation (MT) is one that is widely used. Google Translate translates more than 100 billion words per day right now, so it’s clearly providing useful translations. But it’s not going to take over completely from human translators any time soon (in fact, the US bureau of labor statistics predicts much higher than average employment growth for translators and interpreters between now and 2026). Formal translations, where the text in the target language must be of as high quality as the input — as in the case of legal documents, or literature — still require human translators. There are certain types of blunders that are commonly made by MT systems and without NLU these can’t be reliably guarded against. One example is pronouns (“he”, “she”, “it”, “his”, “hers”, “they”, “their”, etc.), which are notoriously difficult for MT. Cognitive Scientist Douglas Hofstadter wrote last year about what he called the “shallowness” of Google Translate, pointing to its inability to “understand” what it’s translating. Many of Hofstadter’s examples involve mistranslations of pronouns. The reason these cases are so difficult for MT is that to translate a pronoun correctly, you have to know what it’s referring to. We humans perform this task so easily using our knowledge of the world that we hardly even notice we’re doing it. But that’s precisely the skill that machines lack.

Gendered pronouns make the problem especially clear. In some languages, there are no gendered pronouns at all; in others, such as French, the gender of a possessive pronoun agrees with the noun, not with the possessor as in English: the correct translation of the French “sa maison” into English could be either “his house” or “her house”, depending on whose house we’re talking about. While some simple heuristics can help in many cases (e.g., assuming that the pronoun refers to the last mentioned noun), decades of AI research have revealed the general inadequacy of rule-based approaches to natural language. Furthermore, gendered pronouns are probably the most obvious place where bias shows itself in MT applications. You may have seen examples of Turkish sentences translated into English where a genderless pronoun becomes gendered according to what the noun is: “he” for a doctor, “she” for a nurse, and so on. Even giving a massive hint as to what the correct gendered pronoun should be, Google Translate today still defaults to biased guesses:

Seen as an AI problem, this pronoun problem is difficult to solve. Progress to date has mostly come in the form of establishing ways to measure progress on it (see e.g., the GLUE benchmark and the Winograd Schema Challenge). But seen as a software application problem, the pronoun problem is actually easy to solve. In this case, the software application in question is a translation app, and the solution is simply to offer the user a choice of translations in the UI: either “he is a doctor” or “she is a doctor”. To the human user, the answer is obvious and simple. So why not let the user decide? As it happens, that’s exactly the change Google announced recently in their post, Reducing gender bias in Google Translate. But from the screenshot above it’s clear that the solution has only been partially implemented. If you just enter a sentence like the Turkish “o bir doktor”, you’ll get the two gender-specific options, but it seems that if you provide any context at all, the system still trusts itself, so to speak, to guess the correct pronoun from the context. But that’s precisely what it can’t be trusted to get right, for the reasons outlined above.

Something interesting to note about this example is that when there’s no context given, multiple answers are correct, and if a system makes a guess and picks one of them it might simply show off its bias, but it won’t be incorrect. But when context is provided, there’s really only one correct answer, and choosing the other answer will not only (in some cases) show off bias, it’ll just be patently wrong. So it seems to me that it’s actually more important for the system not to guess when context is provided, because in that case it risks a bad translation. And yet Google chose only to implement the fix where just one problem is solved, i.e., the problem of perpetuating gender stereotypes. But it left the problem of mistranslations unaddressed.

Certainly with longer pieces of text it becomes less feasible to offer separate translations, but in these cases problematic pronouns could at least be flagged in some way for the user to handle. In the case of an API call, the caller could specify how they should be handled. The important point is that a straight-up engineering solution is what’s required here, not an AI solution (because currently there isn’t one).

Yoshua Bengio, a core figure in the history of Deep Learning (and in particular, Deep Learning for NLP), was recently asked in a survey of NLP experts about the current direction of the field and the biggest unsolved problems. In response, he spoke about the need for “grounded language learning” and “commonsense understanding” and was critical of current purely data-driven approaches that attempt to make progress without these key elements. He even claimed that attempts to train models that really understand language will be futile “if we do not also solve the harder problem of building world models, i.e., models which understand how our world works, with humans and other agents in it. We need instead to bite the bullet and go for the bigger prize of solving AI altogether with NLP.”

While academic researchers may start to aim for this bigger prize, those of us in industry looking to solve business problems with NLP today need to make do with the techniques that we already have at our disposal, limited as they may be. Neural Network based approaches to NLP have proven to be an enormous step forward when it comes to tasks like text classification, sentiment analysis, and of course machine translation. These methods learn useful numeric representations of words and phrases by consuming vast amounts of text data. The architectures involved in training these systems are getting ever more sophisticated, and pre-trained representations and models are being made available for general use. This is all great, but the sophistication of these models and architectures cannot overcome their inherent limitations: the lack of understanding remains and will inevitably produce errors. Designing applications that use these techniques must include designing for the mistakes they’ll make, even if it means providing a UI that is upfront about the application’s lack of intelligence. I’m betting users will value that honesty, not to mention the improved usefulness of the application.
